articles.author: Tia Goldenberg
articles.description: Top Israeli Cabinet ministers are set to meet to vote on whether to intensify the country’s military operations in the Gaza Strip, as the country's main airport was closed following a missile launched from Yemen. The army has begun to call up thousands of reserve soldiers in preparation for an expanded assault, Israeli officials said Sunday. The plans to escalate fighting in Gaza more than 18 months after the war there erupted come as a humanitarian crisis in the territory deepens. Houthi rebels on Sunday launched a missile that set off air raid sirens in many parts of the country. A large plume of smoke could be seen rising near Ben-Gurion Airport, according to footage shared by Israeli media.
articles.title: Israeli Cabinet ministers to vote on whether to expand Gaza fighting

articles.author: Mohammed Jahjouh, Sarah El Deeb
articles.description: Malnutrition and hunger are prevelant in the Gaza strip as Israel’s blockade enters its third month. Shortage of food and supplies has driven the territory toward starvation. Supplies to treat and pervent malnutrition are depeleted and quickly running out as documented cases of malnutrition rise. Some 3,600 children were admitted and treated for acute malnutrition in the past month_ a figure that is likely rising. Parents are running out of options of what to feed their children and where to take fhem to get help. Images of emaciated children are becoming more frequent and hungry children at community kitchens are fighting for food, alongside adults.
articles.title: Mothers struggle to feed their children in Gaza

articles.author: Sam Metz, Akram Oubachir
articles.description: Morocco's ports have emerged as a flashpoint in protests against the country's decision to normalize ties with Israel. A year and a half of protests have emboldened activists and exposed a gulf between the government and those they govern. Demonstrators from across the political spectrum have taken to the streets to target the country's 4-year-old decision to normalize ties with Israel. Activists accuse the government of disregarding public sentiment and are expanding their targets, which now include the country's strategic ports. Protests swelled this month ahead of the docking of vessels suspected of carrying military cargo as part of a program that includes Israel.
articles.title: Protesters want Morocco to sever ties with Israel, so they're targeting strategic ports

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin said there has been no need to use nuclear weapons in the war in Ukraine and expressed hope that such a scenario will not arise. In a preview aired Sunday of a state TV interview, Putin said Russia has the strength to bring the conflict to a “logical conclusion.” His remarks come amid competing Russian and Ukrainian ceasefire proposals and continued fighting. Ukrainian officials said 11 people, including two children, were wounded in a Russian drone strike on Kyiv overnight. Russia’s Defense Ministry said its air defenses shot down 13 Ukrainian drones.
articles.title: Putin says he hopes nuclear weapons won't be needed in Ukraine

articles.author: Stephen Mcgrath
articles.description: Romanians are casting ballots in a critical presidential election redo after last year’s annulled vote plunged the European Union and NATO member country into its worst political crisis in decades. Eleven candidates are vying for the presidency and a May 18 runoff is expected. A median of local polls suggests George Simion, a MAGA-style hard-right nationalist, will emerge as the frontrunner, likely pitting him against Bucharest Mayor Nicusor Dan, or the governing coalition’s candidate Crin Antonescu.
articles.title: Romanians vote in a presidential redo after voided election sparked deep political crisis

articles.author: Nicole Winfield
articles.description: While Pope Francis accomplished a lot in his 12-year papacy, he left much unfinished business and many challenges for his successor — from the Vatican’s disastrous finances to the wars raging on multiple continents. When the conclave’s cardinals finish casting their ballots in the Sistine Chapel, the 267th pope will have to decide whether to continue with Francis’ policies, radically change them, or abandon them altogether. He also must choose what new projects will take precedence. Among the pressing issues are the role of women in the church, the division between traditionalists and progressives, what to do about clergy sex abuse and whether to LGBTQ+ Catholics.
articles.title: Pope Francis left unfinished business after a 12-year papacy. What challenges await the next pope?

articles.author: Giada Zampano
articles.description: It was the mounting rage of citizens in Viterbo, a small town north of Rome, that ended the longest papal election in the Catholic Church’s history, forging for the first time the word “conclave.” The Viterbo election in the 13th century was a pivotal event in papal history, lasting almost three years due to deep divisions among the cardinals over the name of the new pope. Viterbo is also considered the birthplace of the modern conclave, where cardinals are confined to a single place until they elect a new pontiff and often need to negotiate to reach a compromise on the final name.
articles.title: A roofless palace in Italy's Viterbo hosted the first and longest conclave

articles.author: Nicole Winfield, Jill Colvin
articles.description: President Donald Trump has posted an artificial intelligence-generated image of himself dressed as pope. The social media post comes as the mourning of Pope Francis continues and the papal conclave is set to begin in a few days. The image is raising eyebrows on social media, at the Vatican, from a group representing Catholic bishops in New York and from Italians. Catholics are in the period of official mourning after Francis' death. Catholic cardinals are due to open the solemn conclave to elect his successor on Wednesday. The death of a pope and election of another is a matter of utmost solemnity for Catholics
articles.title: Trump draws criticism with AI image of himself as the pope

articles.author: Jill Lawless
articles.description: British counterterrorism officers have arrested several Iranian men over an alleged plot to attack an unspecified target in London. The Metropolitan Police force said five men aged between 29 and 46 were detained on Saturday in various parts of England on suspicion of preparing a terrorist act. Four are Iranian citizens and the nationality of the fifth is still being established. Three other Iranian men were arrested in London on suspicion of a national security offense as part of a separate investigation, police said. All the suspects are being questioned at police stations and have not been charged. Police said Sunday they were not identifying the suspected target of the alleged plot “for operational reasons.”
articles.title: UK police arrest several Iranian men over alleged attack plot

articles.author: Rod McGuirk
articles.description: Australia’s re-elected Prime Minister Anthony Albanese on Sunday was greeted by well-wishers at a Sydney café and said the country had voted for unity over division. Albanese’s center-left Labor Party won an emphatic victory in elections on Saturday. As vote counting continued, the government was on track to win at least 85 seats in the 150-seat House of Representatives, the lower chamber where parties need a majority to form an administration. Labor held 78 seats in the previous Parliament, and gaining seats in a second term is rare in Australian politics. Albanese told reporters on Sunday: “The Australian people voted for unity rather than division.” Opposition leader Peter Dutton lost his parliamentary seat. His coalition was reduced to 37 seats.
articles.title: Australia's re-elected prime minister says voters chose unity over division
